citation.article-title: Propionimicrobium gen. nov., a new genus to accommodate Propionibacterium lymphophilum (Torrey 1916) Johnson and Cummins 1972, 1057AL as Propionimicrobium lymphophilum comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Propionimicrobium (Pro.pi.on.i.mi.cro'bi.um. N.L. n. acidum propionicum propionic acid; Gr. adj. micros small; Gr. masc. n. bios life. N.L. neut. n. Propionimicrobium propionic acid-producing microbe)
The description is based on data of Holdeman et al. (1977), Cummins & Johnson (1986), 16S rDNA data of Dasen et al. (1998) and our own data.
Pleomorphic rods, 0.5-0.8 μm in diameter x 1-2.5 μm in length, often diphtheroid or club-shaped.
Cells may occur singly, in pairs or short chains, in V or Y configurations or in clumps.
Fermentation end products include propionic acid, acetic acid, succinic acid, iso-valeric acid and lesser amounts of formic acid.
One out of two strains is catalase-positive.
The major menaquinone type is MK-9(H4).
The peptidoglycan contains lysine and aspartic acid (Lys-Asp type).
Major fatty acids are C18:1ω9c, anteiso-C15:0 and C16:0.
TheG­C content of the DNA is 53-54 mol% (Tm) or 56 mol% (HPLC of digested DNA).
Based upon 16S rDNA analysis a member of the family Propionibacteriaceae.
Type species: Propionimicrobium lymphophilum (Torrey 1919) Johnson & Cummins 1972.
